journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part L: Journal of Materials: Design and Applications

title-group.article-title: The influence of high-temperature oxidation resistant titanium aluminide coating on low-cycle fatigue behaviour of titanium alloy IMI 834 at 600 °C

author-notes.corresp: *National Metallurgical Laboratory (CSIR), Jamshedpur 831007, India. email: asokroy@nmlindia.org

abstract.p: The low-cycle fatigue behaviour of titanium alloy IMI 834 was comparatively studied in bare condition and with titanium aluminide (Al2Ti) coating at 600 °C in air. Results revealed that at higher values of total strain amplitudes (Δεt/2), Al2Ti-coated IMI 834 alloy has longer fatigue life (Nf) compared to the bare IMI 834 alloy, which appears to be due to load shifting to the coat. At lower values of Δεt/2, Al2Ti coating on IMI 834 alloy seems to have no effect on Nf. Higher values of cyclic strength coefficient (K′) and cyclic hardening exponent (n′) for coated IMI 834 alloy indicate that coating offers resistance to cyclic plastic deformation at 600 °C in air, and hence it is beneficial. The coating adheres well to the substrate and is also fairly resistant to high-temperature corrosion in sea water atmosphere at 600 °C.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Titanium base near-alpha alloy of IMI 834 grade is used in the high-pressure compressor of several jet engines. High-temperature oxidation resistance coatings on IMI 834 alloy enhance the performance of aero-engines operating in hostile environments [1,2]. People in industry as well as academia are actively pursuing research on evaluating the high-temperature low-cycle fatigue (LCF) behaviour of IMI 834 [3–5] and the effect of high-temperature oxidation resistance coating such as titanium aluminide on LCF life. The microstructural aspects and the LCF behaviour of the substrate have been extensively studied [5–9]. However, the microstructural aspects and the fatigue performance of the titanium aluminide-coated IMI 834 are largely unknown.

This study endeavours to understand the effect of titanium aluminide coating on the LCF behaviour of IMI 834-grade titanium alloy at 600 °C in air. This temperature is chosen as it corresponds to the temperature of the compressed air in the last stage of the compressor disc just before entering the combustion chamber where IMI 834 alloy is used.

sec.title: 2.1 Alloy and heat treatment
sec.p: IMI 834 substrate alloy was received from a defence sector as rods of 25 mm diameter. The as-received rods were solutionized at 1030 ± 5 °C in vacuum for 2 h and then oil quenched. The ageing treatment was carried out at 700 ± 5 °C for 2 h also in vacuum followed by air-cooling. The heat treatment was conducted by the manufacture of the alloy from the defence sector.

sec.title: 2.2 Generation of coatings
sec.p: Titanium aluminide coatings on the gauge length portion of LCF specimens were generated by pack-aluminizing technique at 600 °C for 5 h in argon atmosphere. The composition of the powder used in the pack-aluminizing process was 10 wt% Al–2 wt% NH4Cl and 88 wt% calcined Al2O3 (balance Ti). The coating was characterized under scanning electron microscope (SEM) model JEOL A 91. Beyond 50 µ thickness of the coating, the coating peels off from the substrate and so the coating thickness was optimized at 50 µ only.

sec.title: 2.3 High-temperature corrosion resistance tests
sec.p: The bare and coated alloys were subjected to continuous weight loss measurement tests at 300 °C and 600 °C using an autoclave and muffle furnace, respectively, in 3.5 per cent NaCl solution, at an interval of 6 h. These tests were carried out to study the high-temperature corrosion resistance of the coated sample in sea water atmosphere till about 48 h, and if the coated alloy could be used in marine gas turbine application too. Samples in the form of tablets of 20 mm diameter were chosen. Titanium aluminide coating (~50 µm thick) was generated on all the four faces of the tablets made of solutionized and aged IMI 834 alloy by pack-aluminizing process, as described in section 2.2. During weight loss measurement tests, samples were taken out after every 6 h of exposure, washed with distilled water, dried, and weighed in an electronic balance. At 600 °C, NaCl did not remain in solution but the weight loss tests at 600 °C were similar to salt roasting only.

sec.title: 2.4 LCF tests
sec.p: Round dog bone-shaped LCF specimens with a gaugediameter of 5 mm were fabricated from the heat-treated rods following ASTM standard E606. The coating strongly adhered and did not peel off. Itwas very smooth in appearance and did not even get scratched while fixing the thermocouple in theshoulder above the gauge length and also while fixing theextensometer knife-edge on the gauge length. The LCF tests were conducted at a constant strain rate of 1 × 10−3 s−1 in air and at 600 ± 2 °C. These tests were conducted by controlling the total strainamplitude (Δεt/2) through an extensometer (GL-12.5 mm, travel-±5 mm) at Δεt/2values of 7.5 × 10−3, 9.0 × 10−3, 1.0 × 10−2, and 1.2 × 10−2 for bare and titanium aluminide-coated alloys grade of IMI 834 using an INSTRON servo electric test system model 8862. The fatigue life for all values of Δεt/2 was considered as 20 per cent drop from the highest values of tensile stress amplitude (Δσ/2). LCF-tested samples were examined under SEM for understanding the fatigue failure mechanisms.

sec.title: 3.1 Microstructure
sec.p:
Microstructure of the alloy after heat treatment consists of primary α in transformed β matrix (Fig. 1(a)). The volume fraction of primary α as measured using image analysis software is 15 per cent. The coating on IMI 834 is uniform (Fig. 1(b)), consisting of Al2Ti phase (Fig. 1(c)) and has a thickness of about 50 µm (Fig. 2). X-ray analysis (Fig. 1(c)), taken along the direction of large arrow in Fig. 1(b), shows the elemental distribution across the coating–substrate interface. From the concentration values of Al and Ti in Fig. 1(c), it appears that the Al2Ti is the main intermetallic phase of the coating, which has been confirmed from reference [10]. The interface was found to be devoid of any intermetallics which justifies that it is like a diffusion layer with smooth transition of elements between the coating and the substrate (Fig. 1(c)) and the coating adhered well onto the substrate (Figs 1(b) and 2). Compositions of coating, interface, and substrate by energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS) microanalysis (Fig. 2) also clearly revealed that %Ti is the least in the coating and the maximum in the substrate and %Al was the maximum in the coating and the least in the substrate. Fig. 1
SEM micrographs showing (a) primary α in a transformed β matrix in IMI 834 alloy and (b)coated IMI 834 alloy with a sharp coating–substrate interface. Part of the coating is shown; (c) X-ray profile of the elements across the coating–substrate interface [11] Fig. 2
SEM micrograph of fatigue-failed Al2Ti-coated IMI 834 alloy which failed at Δεt/2 = 1.2 × 10−2 showing coating, interface, and substrate. EDS microanalysis showing composition of (a) coating, (b) interface, and (c) substrate. The coating is well adhered to the substrate. The micrograph reveals a typical transgranular rupture in the substrate

sec.title: 3.2 Chemical composition and tensile property of the substrate
sec.p:
The chemical composition (in mass%) of the investigated alloy (Table 1) is 5.8Al, 4Sn, 3.5Zr, 0.7Nb, 0.5Mo, 0.35Si, 0.06C, and balance Ti. The tensile properties at the maximum application temperature (600 °C) of IMI 834 alloy are given in Table 1. Table 1
Chemical composition and mechanical properties at the maximum application temperature (600 °C) of the Ti-based alloy
Alloy designation Composition YS (MPa) UTS (MPa) % RA % EL
IMI 834 Ti-based alloy Ti–5.8Al–4Sn–3.5Zr–0.7Nb–0.5Mo–0.35Si–0.06C 577 679 57 20

sec.title: 3.3 High-temperature corrosion resistance tests
sec.p:
The coating revealed excellent corrosion resistance to sea water at 300 °C as there was almost no mass loss up to 48 h (Fig. 3(a)). However, at 600 °C, during salt roasting, possibly due to the formation of volatile chlorides like titanium tetrachloride mainly [12], there was some loss of mass of the coating as well as bare substrate, initially up to about 12 h (Fig. 3(b)). However, both the coated and uncoated alloys were resistant to high-temperature corrosion, in sea water atmosphere at 600 °C after about 12 h of exposure. Since Ti has greater affinity to Cl− [12], it is anticipated that the probability of formation of volatile titanium tetrachloride is higher than that of aluminium chloride [12]. However, it is noteworthy that at 600 °C, mass loss in bare IMI834 alloy in the initial 12 h of exposure is less than that for the coated substrate. This is because in the coating, Al2Ti is in the form of an intermetallic phase, and the probability of formation of any amount of aluminium chloride in the coating due to exposure in NaCl at 600 °C is higher than that in the bare alloy, which eventually also evaporates. Fig. 3
Variation of mass with time of exposure in 3.5 per cent NaCl solution at (a) 300 °C and (b)600 °C of coated and bare Ti alloy IMI 834

sec.title: 3.4 LCF tests
sec.p:
The LCF test specimen geometry is shown in Fig. 4(a). LCF tests exhibited that plastic strain amplitude is thedamage parameter controlling the fatigue life for both the bare as well as Al2Ti-coated IMI 834 alloys. The hysteresis loops corresponding to saturation atdifferent values of Δεt/2 are shown in Fig. 4(b). Deformation curves of coated and bare IMI 834 alloys at different values of Δεt/2 are revealed in Fig. 4(c). The plastic strain amplitude values at saturation (Nf/2) i.e. (Δεpl/2)s were then plotted against total number of reversals (2Nf) (Fig. 4(d)), following the Coffin–Manson relationship as stated in equation (1) (1) where c is the fatigue ductility exponent and ε′f the fatigue ductility coefficient. At 600 °C, IMI834 exhibits cyclic softening [3–9] and Fig. 4(c), i.e. plastic strain amplitude is not constant anymore. The material loses strength due to change in slip mode, dissolution of α2-particles, and silicide coarsening [9]. The plastic strain amplitude in this investigation was calculated corresponding to half-life/saturation. The values of total strain amplitudes (Δεt/2), the half-life (Nf/2), plastic strain amplitude (Δεpl/2)s, and stress amplitude (Δσ/2)s corresponding to half-life/saturation employed for the LCF tests are listed in Table 2. At constant strain rate i.e. 1 × 10−3 s−1 and constant temperature i.e. 600 °C, the values of c and ε′f for bare and Al2Ti-coated IMI 834 alloys are collated in Table 3 and they fall in the range reported by earlier authors for the bare substrate [3–9]. From Coffin–Manson plot (Fig. 4(d)), it is inferred that the LCF life of the coated alloy was marginally higher at higher values of plastic strain amplitudes than that of the bare alloy compared to lower values of plastic strain amplitude. In other words, at higher values of total strain amplitudes (Δεt/2), Al2Ti-coated IMI 834 alloy has longer fatigue life (Nf) compared to the bare IMI 834 alloy but at lower values of Δεt/2, Al2Ti coating on IMI 834 alloy seems to have no effect on Nf. This possibly could be due, in part, to load pickup by the intermetallic coating (Al2Ti). Based on a 0.05-mm thick Al2Ti coating around the circumference of a 5-mm gauge diameter of the current LCF samples, the potential load-bearing area would be increased by ~4.1 per cent. Thus, even a small pickup of load by the intermetallic coating cross-sectional area would reduce the effective bare alloy stress by the same amount, which would make the coated alloy samples stronger than bare alloy specimens. At low-plastic strain amplitudes, oxidation might not be a problem for the bare substrate as specimens tested at (Δεpl/2)s value 2.3 × 10−3 failed at nearly 1.3 × 103 cycles (Fig.4(d)). Such a behaviour is comparable to a room temperature LCF life of IMI 834 alloy at similar (Δεpl/2)s value [3]. Previous high-cycle fatigue testing of bare, bond-coated, and TBC-coated Superni C-263 at 800 °C in air revealed that the coated materials hadhigher endurance limits than the bare superalloy, which appears to be due to load shifting to the bond coat [13]. The difference between the 800 °C endurance limits between the bare and coated superalloyscould be also be due, in part, to load pickup by the bond coat. While considering the relative mechanical properties of the superalloy (Superni C-263) [13] and the overlay coating, the latter has a low-strength dueto the numerous defects and a lower elastic modulus. For a 0.1-mm thick bond coat on 3 × 4 mm samples [13], the possible load-bearing area of bond coat is 12 per cent of that of the superalloy; thus, even a small pickup of stress (load) by the bond coat cross-sectional area, such as 20 or 30 MPa, would reduce the effective superalloy stress by the same amount, which would make the coated superalloy samples appear to be much stronger than bare superalloy specimens [13]. Previous compressive testing of overlay-coated substrates [11], such as Ni–18Cr–12Al–0.5Y, at 800 °C, has indicated that a creep stress ~25 MPa will result in a creep rate of 10−7 s−1, while ~300 MPa is required to deform at 10−3 s−1; thus, partial support of the applied loads by the bond coat alloy could result in apparent strengthening. Fig. 4
(a) Schematic of the specimen used for LCF tests. (b) Cyclically stabilized loops for bare and coated IMI 834 alloys at different values of total strain amplitude. (c) Deformation curves of coated and bare IMI 834 alloys at different values of Δεt/2. (d) Coffin–Manson plots for bare and Al2Ti coated Ti IMI 834 alloys. (e) CSSC for bare and Al2Ti coated Ti IMI 834 alloys Table 2

Δεt/2 Nf/2 (Δεpl/2)s (Δσ/2)s, MPa
Bare IMI 834

1.0 × 10−2 175 3.741 × 10−3 530

Values of ε′f and c derived from Coffin–Manson relationship and K′ and n′ derived from CSSC
Material ε′f C K′ n′
Bare 0.0407 −0.378 1256 0.16
Coated 0.0908 −0.49 1785 0.24

The cyclic stress–strain curve (CSSC) was plotted following equation (2) (2) where K′ is the cyclic strength coefficient and n′ the cyclic hardening exponent. The CSSCs for bare and Al2Ti-coated IMI 834 alloys are shown in Fig. 4(e). The corresponding K′ and n′ values are listed in Table 2, which agree well with those reported in literature for the bare alloy [3–9]. Higher values of cyclic strength coefficient (K′) and cyclic hardening exponent (n′) for coated IMI 834 alloy indicated that coating offers resistance to cyclic plastic deformation at 600 °C in air, and hence it is beneficial. The alloy is prone to high-temperature oxidation and Al2Ti coating on IMI 834 alloy appears to be a high-temperature oxidation resistance coating [1,2] particularly to LCF damage in an oxidizing environment. Fractographic feature of the fatigue-failed samples conducted at Δεt/2 = 7.5 × 10−3 mainly revealed transgranular failure with the presence of fatigue striations both in the coated as well as in the bare substrates (Fig. 5), which are the typical features of fatigue failure. Fig. 5
SEM fractograph showing transgranular failure with fatigue striations in (a) bare and (b)coated IMI 834 ruptured samples in LCF tests conducted at Δεt/2 = 7.5 × 10−3

list-item.p: At higher values of total strain amplitudes (Δεt/2), Al2Ti-coated IMI 834 alloy has longer fatigue life (Nf) compared to the bare IMI 834 alloy which appears to be due to load shifting to the coat, butat lower values of Δεt/2, Al2Ti coating on IMI 834 alloy seems to have no effect on Nf.

Higher values of cyclic strength coefficient (K′) and cyclic hardening exponent (n′) for coated IMI 834 alloy indicated that Al2Ti coating offers resistance to cyclic plastic deformation at 600 °C in air, and hence it is beneficial.
The coating adheres well to the substrate and was fairly resistant to high-temperature corrosion in sea water atmosphere at 600 °C.
